116FAD5FC60B4E2ABA6F5596CD0BECB8.description: Be willing to consider the consequences of their consumer choices.

31CABEF9600548CB81293EBBD507E7E9.description: Appreciate that quality of life is not solely determined by access to wealth, resources, and technologies.

1F18236942094B2F80AED317E4684CB0.description: Give examples of the environmental and social impact of consumerism in the local community and in a society of Europe or the Americas.

ACE39C3714FA4E469A840E7A996F814E.description: Describe sustainable development issues in a society of Europe or the Americas.

0F9CB7D415E14C0EA5A95B7A8F57AC38.description: Identify issues related to food production and distribution in a society of Europe or the Americas.

D4D62CCD30544452924DEFA1DAD50432.description: Identify common challenges faced by large urban centres. Examples: economic, environmental, social.

C6BD60C7D6D34306B1527432DCF90191.description: Identify major economic activities in a society of Europe or the Americas.

97A2DD8EFEBE4EAA8F4F491DFA39FD79.description: Identify issues related to work and trade in a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia. Examples: child labour, exploitation in or exclusion from the workforce, cooperatives, fair trade.

35BA06055EB646C283ACDC9881165C37.description: Give examples of the impact of changing technologies on ways of life in a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia.

5B901D3842AB4057B17762749A4BF5A4.description: Describe the impact of urbanization and industrialization on indigenous peoples in a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia.

4D5F869846CD4AF38C1B92B2850C5864.description: Identify major economic activities in a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia.

C2FD9EA5CF3848A9812E427BD7A1C61B.description:
Give examples of the uneven distribution of
wealth and resources in the world and
describe the impact on individuals,
communities, and nations.

83D5228FEC40497E8A299162CE6F74EE.description: Demonstrate concern for the loss of indigenous ways of life.

21CCB7A3447744729D49DEA53182318D.description: Appreciate the positive contributions of various individuals to world affairs.

D0D43C293105494782ABA22D900698A2.description: Demonstrate concern for people who are affected by discrimination, injustice, or abuse of power.

669728D0B6F045158C8669D0A2283354.description: Identify ways in which government decisions may affect human impact on the natural environment.

6842839266464F9D8E20727FEB01C955.description: Give examples of the impact of government and the justice system on ways of life in a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia.

CC8D574B4F7446EA90D175780BF08FAF.description: Identify various individuals who influence world affairs.

02194967DEEB44B988EF01F3732E610F.description: Explain the relationship between power and access to wealth and resources.

F4C8E4C43D6C494AB3D1ACFAE0A2ED69.description: Compare and contrast various types of power and authority.

604AF3B9EACA4B2AAE208E2C212CAFD8.description: Give examples of government decisions that affect quality of life.

1A159B0EF50C4DCCAF680C647BEFE519.description:
Compare the accuracy of various map
projections and describe their influence on
perceptions of the size and importance of the
continents.
Examples: Goode, Mercator, Peters,
Robinson, polar.

D496E80C9CF74F43AB6105DDCFD7BE7E.description: Demonstrate interest in ways of life of other societies in the world.

E807988FE1F74482A036CE51EFBA7364.description: Value the contributions of international agencies and humanitarians to quality of life. Examples: Mennonite Central Committee, Red Cross; Nelson Mandela, Mother Teresa.

DA2843D4F29B490E94DC4745587350B8.description: Identify universal human rights and explain their importance.

B43B3C7CE9274DCC9CE73611B533C48E.description: Identify various international organizations and describe their role in protecting or enhancing global quality of life. Examples: United Nations, Amnesty International, Greenpeace, Médecins sans frontières.

CEF0E2764FCA475895E6E786519D5EAB.description: Identify reasons why people emigrate. KG-035 Give examples of global cooperation to solve conflicts or disasters.

8407F57FEBF84B7F96F1BF63198938C1.description: Give examples of events and achievements that enhance understanding among peoples and nations. Examples: international sporting events, world fairs and expositions, film, music, and literary festivals, Nobel Prizes.

A6F72FAD68814D8CAECF9B6963CC3AFF.description:
Identify on a world map the more and less
developed nations and explain why a nation is
considered to be more or less developed.

3BD3BFC77CF8452385D938956BA5764B.description: Appreciate history as an important way to understand contemporary life.

1D624ECA12E44E19BC2A14BCCCC6A9A0.description: Identify historical events that continue to affect a society of Europe or the Americas. Examples: colonization, slavery, wars, disasters, agricultural or technological change.

5CB11FFF0C414968B46469D06F3DAC78.description:
Identify historical events that continue to
affect a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia.
Examples: colonization, slavery, wars,
disasters.

2BEDD5697D5B4DB685370F0D9822F54C.description: Be willing to take actions to help sustain the natural environment in Canada and the world

A621867D2B184EE597C240B61B840C93.description: Appreciate the diversity of the global natural environment.

673E201E37EB4E67903E9F2014C6CBE9.description: Give examples of the impact of human activity on the natural environment in a society of Europe or the Americas. Examples: endangered plant and animal species, reforestation, restoration of wetlands.

67BB99EC125448ED925D83CDC6B39843.description: Describe diverse approaches to land and natural resource use in a society of Europe or the Americas.

976B47A8A9AE4C5DAEBC750428DBC9AF.description: Describe social, environmental, and economic consequences of climate change.

37969FB0255C4F13B4E4FD4657AE08BA.description: Identify human activities that contribute to climate change.

BD0212678ED74425A14D1927B25FE1A9.description: Give reasons for increased urbanization in a society of Europe or the Americas. Examples: housing, access to services, employment, industry.

C2171798F3094280BCD46BFD8DAC967D.description: Identify on a map the major cities, landforms, and bodies of water of a society of Europe or the Americas.

6105C05BB2ED48ADA7E22C84E8246C7F.description: Give examples of the influence of the natural environment on ways of life in a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia.

9E696DD3151B415B9CF4853C0B0392B5.description: Identify on a map the major cities, landforms, and bodies of water of a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia.

163B81C0ACC74578B21079971A5F2687.description: Explain standards related to time zones. Include: International Date Line, Universal Time, local time.

9FFD0874AB02404AB1A05DE2F891846A.description: Locate the time zones on a world map and explain their purpose.

DF639501031D4EE5A03679C5900500BA.description: Identify factors that influence the movement of people around the world. Examples: environmental, economic, political, social.

EBE4A3CD16784857908AA1A0F397AF0D.description: Locate on a world map the major francophone countries.

1AD15DADF52945B89CC91E39106737FE.description: Locate on a world map the major population clusters and explain the relationship between population distribution and the natural environment.

DDADF2556D664B23AD75072DD479544B.description: Locate on a world map and describe the major climatic and vegetation zones.

FADA0E13D0B64118BB06702F2D020B87.description: Locate on a world map the continents, major landforms, and major bodies of water.

E71AC958D6E046BE9D70723D4940950A.description:
Explain the purpose of latitude, longitude,
parallels, and meridians.

8CEAB24493A4433CBEC6FF6C672D30B6.description: Appreciate the importance of cultural and linguistic diversity in the world

C77E8B260EAB46B7A1096E4EAC15FA17.description: Be willing to broaden personal perspectives and experiences beyond the familiar.

0F7FABCD8400448A91FE577078398C27.description: Respect others’ rights to express their points of view.

12CB8D2F20B643AB99496A5197B8A01D.description: Describe characteristics of indigenous ways of life in a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia.

102263F94E9A4F92874D446E8A16A71E.description: Describe factors that affect health in a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia. Examples: access to safe water, food, and medical care; AIDS and other epidemics.

AB8B581CD3B947E682D6CF9739778135.description: Describe the influence of westernization in a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia. Examples: cultural homogenization, global communication.

486EB92D36F34C50B0B9E3498FA25B6B.description: Give examples of the artistic expression of culture in a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia. Examples: art, music, dance, literature, oral tradition.

1C8BB374CBB84539AFC6C0D590339FE3.description: Give examples of cultural factors that shape ways of life in a society of Asia, Africa, or Australasia.

9BBF810269544FA3B8C41406C9538E4E.description: Identify elements that all societies have in common. Examples: social structure, communication, art, beliefs, technology, governance, economic organization.

C5952B09A23E4D7FAEF2C33E242FA312.description: Describe the influence of various factors on personal identity. Examples: gender and gender images, sexual orientation, physical characteristics, socioeconomic situation, peer pressure, media portrayals.

61B28CC79B7E4A808D26545D437719B2.description: Describe the impact of discriminatory attitudes and practices on quality of life. Include: racism, prejudice, stereotyping.

DC9B42F0A18B47C58130A591B2CC4142.description:
Identify diverse cultural and social
perspectives regarding quality of life.
Examples: differing concepts of poverty and
wealth; materialism.

71C4DE4B8B1C40978D3FADF99451E3A2.description: Be willing to take action to support quality of life for people around the world.

2DE11695C0AF4DAF8DCA47C9A758D44F.description: Be willing to contribute to their groups and communities.

DCAB96ABF52F4F1BB5637DB960EB4F3D.description: Acknowledge that the rights of citizenship involve limitations on personal freedom for the sake of collective quality of life.

F5418DC0C2AF47DDB426B540152680C4.description: Respect the inherent dignity of all people.

B2B1734629D1437EB126385FA6B53A9E.description: Recognize Remembrance Day as a commemoration of Canadian participation in world conflicts.

949089A3CA1B4BFC9855904F049C4AF0.description: Describe ways in which their personal actions may affect quality of life for people elsewhere in the world. Examples: consumer choices, conservation actions, sharing of resources, letters and petitions.

763135C12BDD4721ABE7BBBD14FC874D.description: Give examples of ways in which quality of life may be enhanced within a democracy. Examples: freedom of association, speech, and the press; universal suffrage.

7906B1AEF04E4DAEAD0F5BA423CD4ED5.description: Describe the impact of various factors on quality of life in Canada and elsewhere in the world. Examples: access to shelter, food, water, health care, and education; globalization.

51BCB1CE14554E44962421E29DE37F01.description:
Describe the impact of various factors on
citizenship rights in Canada and elsewhere in
the world.
Examples: laws, culture, labour practices,
education.

73E472A49EF84C0896EE6076392E8090.description: Articulate their beliefs and perspectives on issues.

4AD59548E52F49589F90B37ADC5E412E.description: Elicit and clarify questions and ideas in discussions.

74648EF58B974FB2AE3B54F30B09A318.description: Present information and ideas orally, visually, concretely, or electronically.

EA3092CE4AA049DCBB0CB1E3FA8A1706.description: Persuasively express differing viewpoints regarding an issue.

9965F4DA56FD45288A85FFC4D2F92938.description: Use language that is respectful of human diversity.

7232628A691142C998FF9FDEA259A380.description:
Listen to others to understand their
perspectives.

604CD4F43BE242A69B0B636876A16655.description: Analyze prejudice, racism, stereotyping, or other forms of bias in the media and other information sources.

56326ED884CC4B70958B94E5B52DAE62.description: Recognize that interpretations of history are subject to change as new information is uncovered or acknowledged.

FC615E49C5524CBFB82B2F47AEB7C315.description: Interpret information and ideas in a variety of media. Examples: art, music, historical fiction, drama, primary sources.

CEB626EC06D54B7A94BE1A9A85100C11.description: Compare diverse perspectives in the media and other information sources.

A036E1334F6249C381D98ADD9D8A6D84.description: Compare differing viewpoints regarding global issues.

E029E023A87A4B8CA3B5AC87D203F02C.description: Assess the validity of information sources. Examples: purpose, context, authenticity, origin, objectivity, evidence, reliability...

EF099188C889425BB7A22F9CAA3C8752.description: Observe and analyze material and visual evidence for research. Examples: artifacts, photographs, works of art.

E5C449D6A42D423E95226C4936F7DF63.description: Distinguish fact from opinion and interpretation.

7328DA7328CE4494AF08BFBBC98F3C5A.description: Evaluate personal assumptions based on new information and ideas.

1AE02CB3C7D7475885AC42441044EDD6.description: Draw conclusions based on research and evidence.

40CDE458A6704D7B9B783C756ED64F59.description: Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of solutions to a problem.

B463768C0CE540C599ACD486F6816350.description:
Plan topics, goals, and methods for inquiry
and research.

1B62209D23CA473FB04F81E1CCC79D6A.description: Orient themselves by observing the landscape, using traditional knowledge, or using a compass or other tools and technologies.

FD6A8A8DF67F4C01B5DD68B225EF8F81.description: Use traditional knowledge to read the land.

E78F27F5B3CD46FF94B69BB828D68340.description: Use latitude and longitude to locate and describe places on maps and globes.

6AFF18BA41594361B4B4F708EBECC25E.description: Select and interpret various types of maps for specific purposes.

EA20C97C694E4857AD72EB384059F377.description: Construct maps that include a title, legend, compass rose, scale, and latitude and longitude.

92B17E9603964DF2A040C763411BA020.description: Create maps using a variety of information sources, tools, and technologies. Examples: observation, traditional knowledge, geographic information systems (GIS), Global Positioning Systems (GPS).

47F86B7A03AF49CC8153512B16EBDC14.description: Select and use appropriate tools and technologies to accomplish tasks.

A7C8D723B84245A99C0DB2EA8AF5D8A5.description: Interpret primary and secondary information sources for research.

D733D87200094BF2A9965BB156BA3F30.description: Organize and record information in a variety of formats and reference sources appropriately. Examples: maps, charts, outlines, concept maps.

5919B83450494AD3B3C93238DE3BA975.description:
Select information from a variety of oral,
visual, material, print, or electronic sources.
Examples: maps, atlases, art, songs, artifacts,
narratives, legends, biographies, historical
fiction.

E9D5734C243343AE80D4310F986ACEAE.description: Treat places and objects of historical significance with respect. Examples: burial grounds, memorials, artifacts.

98B245D2EAC94784BC1DB06D394E989F.description: Recognize bias and discrimination and propose solutions. Examples: racism, ageism, heterosexism.

7F0ECEF484F848209F010DC020020946.description: Negotiate constructively with others to build consensus and solve problems.

CE7311FB795D482C93DA174FD76AEB40.description: Make decisions that reflect the principles of sustainable development.

DAD5DA19A087433291538BCD350709E7.description: Make decisions that reflect fairness and equality in their interactions with others.

0050AD9992BF4918A6979CEA13CCE9D9.description: Use a variety of strategies to resolve conflicts peacefully and fairly. Examples: clarification, negotiation, compromise..

3012EA4F66764D27975A58B040EF9107.description:
Collaborate with others to establish and carry
out goals and responsibilities.
